g.text: The average friction forces for di
erent depths of ball defects are shown in Figure
perfect substrate, or where the defects are closer to the surface of the substrate, the average friction
forces are increased with the increase in the depth of the defects. In this work, when
the average friction force is the highest. When the depth is greater than 3.615 nm, the average friction
forces decrease with the increase in depth, and the average friction forces gradually approach that of
the perfect substrate, which means that the e
ects of subsurface defects on friction become slight when
the depth reaches a certain value.
Average friction forces for different depths of defects.
Due to the existence of the ball defects, the surrounding atoms reach a new equilibriumstate to
produce the lattice distortion, which changes the material properties. In addition, compared with
the perfect substrate, the defects make the sliding process unstable, and atoms near the defects of the
substrate collapse during the sliding process. For the substrate contains defects, the common neighbor
analysis shows that the dislocations are more than those of perfect substrate, as shown in Figure
With the increase in dislocation density, the shear strength of material increases, which increases the
dissipation energy required to break the bond between atoms during the sliding process, and the
The dislocation of substrate during sliding process. (
Using an EAM potential, MD simulations have been carried out to study the effects of FCC
copper textured surfaces with different depths, widths, orientations and shapes on friction behaviors
during nanoscale sliding contacts. The influence of subsurface defects on the substrate is also
discussed. Under the conditions and material used in this paper, some conclusions are drawn, as
Compared with a smooth surface, textured surfaces can reduce friction forces effectively. In
addition, the textured surfaces with a higher depth and smaller width lead to lower average
For the texture surfaces with the orientations of 0° and 90°, the average friction forces are higher
than those with orientations of 30°, 45° and 60°, and the textured surface with 45° orientation
produces the lowest average friction force.
The effects of texture shape on friction behaviors are slight compared with the effects of depth,
width and orientation, and the v-shape shows a lower average friction force.
The nanoscale ball defects in the substrate make the sliding process unstable. In this paper, when
the depth of the ball defects is
= 3.615 nm, the influence of defects on the average friction force
is the greatest. When the depth is greater than 3.615 nm, the average friction forces decrease with
the increase in depth, and they tend to be close to that of a perfect substrate.
Conceptualization, R.T.; methodology, R.T., Z.Q., Y.Z. and B.H.; software, Z.Q. and B.H.;
formal analysis, R.T. and Z.Q.; investigation, R.T., Z.Q. and Y.Z.; writing—original draft preparation, Z.Q.;
writing—review and editing, R.T.; visualization, Z.Q.; supervision, R.T.; project administration, R.T. and G.L.;

Young Scholars of Northwestern Polytechnical University.
The authors declare no conflict of interest. The funders had no role in the design of the
study; in the collection, analyses, or interpretation of data; in the writing of the manuscript, or in the decision to
The dislocation of substrate during sliding process. (
Inmacro-contact mechanics, the stress distributionof twocontact bodies showedthat the maximum
stress occurred at the subsurface. There was a similar phenomenon in nanoscale contacts, and the
position of maximumstress showed a certain distance fromthe surface [
the radius of the contact body, the applied load and the material properties. If the defects are located
near the position of the maximumstress, or they coincide with each other, the inﬂuence of the defects
on the sliding process will be greater. On the other hand, if the defects are far away fromthe position
